ratings.comment: Professor Cahill is enjoyable if you are a history nerd who likes sitting and viewing archaeology images. He uses no text or slides so be prepared to take heavy notes, as exams are based on how much you can remember about specific items. In office hours and email he is accessible and nice, and grades very fairly. Not an easy credit, but interesting

Cahill's lectures were very disorganized as he didn't use any slides, he just displayed images and talked about them. He also didn't use notes which led to very hard to follow rambling and him repeating himself. The grading criteria for exams and 10-page term paper were unclear, he's a harsh grader, and he sometimes takes weeks to get grades back.

Grading is based on papers and in-class essays. If you struggle with organizing papers don't take this class. Cahill is clearly knowledgeable and passionate about the subject matter and willing to answer questions in class.

Super bad with tech and organization in general. Lots of readings and difficult exams. Picky about being accommodating, also is really in love with Jesus so if you don't know Christianity- good luck! Word of advice: just don't take this class.

Cahill is one of the most passionate and interesting profs I've had in college. He's super knowledgable and you can tell he genuinely loves what he's doing. It helps that I was already interested in the course topic, so take that into consideration when choosing a class. He can be a little disorganized when it comes to using canvas.

Mr. Cahill was a great professor but did go on tangents that are unrelated to the current topic and would expect you to remember a vase that was talked about for a day. The quizzes are easy but he doesn't remind you when they are so study the day before at least. There were 3 papers and no final exam so all in all, it was a good class.

Although it is obvious that Prof. Cahill is very knowledgeable about art history, particularly his own research specificities, it is just as clear how far removed he is from the lives of his students. He gives short, undeveloped feedback on assignments and offers to answer questions but is unapproachable. His lectures are disorganized and scattered

I have taken multiple classes of his, and have loved every one of them. He is very fair with grading, and is always willing to help his students. I have never met a kinder professor. His lectures are engaging, and his assessments are fair. During COVID he was one of the few professors that was adamant about accommodating students.

I was very nervous taking Cahill as a psych major who wandered into an intermediate art history course that fulfilled no requirement. A vast amount of information is covered so the first weeks will be intimidating. If you go to lecture, take notes (somehow), read the textbook and review before exams ur good. This would be super hard in person tho.

Literally one of my favorite profs I have ever had. Very laid back and kind. Sometimes a little disorganized, but hes always happy to clarify or help! Knows that the pandemic affects things, and is realistic in his expectations. He genuinely cares about the material and his students!

Great guy, had him for Art. Hist. 300, really knowledgeable. Sometimes it's easy to dose off in lectures if the topic isn't interesting to you as he just talks and flips through slides. Easy grader, I didn't read all of the textbook but probably necessary. Take notes in lecture.

Lectures are a little disorganized and feel random at times, but overall the assignments are easy. There are 4 one page papers, two midterms, and a final 5-6 page paper worth 40% of your grade. Professor Cahill is really passionate and a funny guy.!!

I had taken an ARTHIS class at my last college and enjoyed it so thought I'd like this one too. Nope. I could tell Nick was very passionate about his work, but lectures felt very disorganized and random. Lots of babbling. We didn't get a syllabus for the whole semester and grading was unclear. He's a nice guy but his teaching style was not for me.

Cahill was great: passionate about his subject and an engaging lecturer. Grades are from 4 1-page papers (easy A's if you attend and read the chapter, due on weeks of your choice), two midterms that require familiarity with objects from lectures, but quite doable, and one final paper that I got 100% on without too much time. Difficulty is a 2.5

Prof. Cahil is very knowledgeable. He structures his lectures as slideshows of various pieces of art, and explores deeper connections. If you pay attention in class, the exams are not too difficult. Papers do require significant effort.

Gets way too carried away with irrelevant info during lecture. I was always bored or distracted. I read the textbook for info on everything which was better. TA was not great. 3 quizzes, 2 papers and 3 exams make up whole grade. Don't take if you don't have to. Not great with technology. Get organized at beginning of semester so you are prep

Cahill is great. His lecture style is very casual, but pay attention: quizzes require lots of detailed knowledge. I went to his office hours to talk about ancient architecture, and he's super knowledgeable. I'd highly recommend taking his class.

Cahill is probably the most wonderful professor I have ever had. He's extremely knowledgable about the subject and you can clearly see how passionate he is about the field. He does use "um" a lot but after the first lecture I didn't really care because I was so enraptured by what he was teaching. Totally recommend him !!!!!
Knows his stuff

Professor Cahill's class is great and his enthusiasm for the subject is clear. His expectations are somewhat high, so be prepared to put in some work for the papers, but he's definitely willing to send you in the right direction during office hours. Hint: He really likes it when your papers cite historical sources (Plato, Homer, etc).

Prof. Cahill is really passionate about what he teaches, as well as incredibly knowledgeable about it. His lectures consist of him showing pictures and explaining them, which can get boring. However, tests are fairly easy as long as you keep up with book readings and study the night before. Final project requires time and effort. He's awesome tho.

He's very knowledgable and passionate about what he does. He knows the topics firsthand from his own research. Not super articulate but very insightful. Don't be afraid to ask questions and be prepared to not get away with BSing anything.

Great Prof. He is AWFUL at outline though, same with essay prompts so ask questions and make sure you understand what is going on. He is clearly VERY intelligent and knows his stuff. If you are interested in ancient I don't think you would find a better professor. Reading is also helpful but not really necessary.
Professor Cahill really loves what he does and you can tell in his lectures.

I am not an art history major but loved this class! Lectures are interesting - content for tests come straight from lecture and textbook. Study a week before not the night before, no way to memorize the content in one day. Cahill is passionate about the subject which makes lectures enjoyable.

Professor Cahill is a really great professor, he always stresses about wanting us to learn more about the object or piece of art  than just simply the dates and where it is from. In all honesty, as long as you go to his lectures and learn the why part to each piece of art, and study the dates and places a little each day, you will pass the class.
Cahill is a great professor. Very intresting and engaging. The course itself is a little boring, I'd recommend a higher level course with him where he can go into the detail he clearly wants to!

I love Professor Cahill! He clearly loves his subject matter - his interest pours over into his lectures. He really likes helping students after class & during his office hours; he's extremely knowledgeable & friendly & happy to answer questions. Definitely attend lectures, because they're super interesting. Overall, Cahill is a truly great guy.

He's really excited about the material, but sometimes it's hard to keep up. Definitely recommend using a laptop. Must attend all lectures or at least get notes. Quizs are a lot of memorizing. Lectures are interesting material.

He taught the a rotational class so it was obvious he was not really interested in the material, but if you are interested in greek, architecture or hellenism then he is your man. the class would have been easier had the lectures been more a little more engaging. read your book, study in advance and befriend you t.a. for the papers due.

He isn't the best speaker, as others have noted, and sometimes the point he's trying to make isn't quite clear.  All in all though he makes the subject fairly interesting and is accessible for students.

Prof Cahill says "um" all the time, and has a hard time getting to the point.  There were several times per lecture he would start to say something then get distracted by another thought and forget what he was saying.  He's a nice guy, but very scatter brained.

I'm not sure what the previous comments are about but this guy is a pain. Every other word he says is either "Uh," or "Um", and it's difficult to sit there for an hour and a half trying to pay attention to what's necessary. Excess images on website, hard to study for, too many slide identifications on exam, not enough time. Discussion's fun though.

Lectures are not necessary but I would still attend to earn brownie points, (lecture is about 30 people). No tests, just one-page weekly assignments and 2 papers. Papers are demanding, but if you do solid research (aka actually use the library and JSTOR) you will get an A. No textbook, only PDFs and reserved books at Chazen (creates headaches).

Generally good stuff. He's got a big dig in Turkey and had to miss a lot of classes. That was frustrating, as the class fell pretty far behind. The Roman House paper at the end was not difficult, as long as you give it enough time.

He is really enthused about the material and knows his stuff. The tests are straightforward and the assignments are easy enough. He likes to put stuff not covered extensively in class on exams so everything is given even treatment instead of beating on subject to death.
He is extremely engaging and makes class interesting. Lectures are pretty important to attend. If you get a good TA and are good at memorizing then it's an easy A. Work is involved.

I loved this class - it was taught extremely well and we had only to write papers for our midterms/final. As long as you wrote the papers, your grade was fine since lecture material has little to do with the papers. I would recommend attending the lectures anyway since they are fascinating, though sometimes he rehashes information several times.

This is the second class I've had with Cahill (the first being AH201).  He's one of the most engaging professors I've ever had, and he's genuinely interested in his students and helping them out.  The subject matter is not my personal cup of tea, but he made much of it very interesting.  His enthusiasm for ancient art and civilization is boundless!

I wasn't too interested when I signed up for it, but it's great! I love Cahill, he's awesome. Very knowledgeable about stuff and makes it interesting. Takes attendance once a week usually, but if you go to lecture you don't really have to read much. Take this class! It's pretty easy!

soo this class kind of sucked.. i really like classical topics and art hisroty and it was cool that professor cahil liked the class so much but to tell you the truth, the class was straight up boring and usless.. we looked at pots and rubble. not whole pots or whole buildings, shards. and rubble. take at your own risk.

Cahill is always at least 3-5 minutes late, and many times, he went over the 50 minutes, which made it hard to get to classes which were farther away, which was annoying.  He has tons of enthusiasm for the subject and it was fairly interesting, but if you don't like memorizing tons and tons of objects and info for each test, don't take this class.

Cahill is very excited about what he teaches so if you are interested in this type of material you will enjoy him as a professor. I didn't like the class but I didn't like most of the material. Be prepared to memorize and memorize and memorize......
Makes class interesting, exams straightforward, essay questions given ahead of time.

I basically took this class for the credit and ended up loving it.  Cahill is a great prof and very nice.  He's super enthusiastic and is extremely educated.  If you are confused about something in class don't be afraid to ask him and look stuff up in the book.  A LOT OF MEMORIZATION, and studying before tests.  Go in for help if needed for papers

He's very enthusiastic about his subject and is nice to all his students. He encourages you to analyze the art. There's a lot of memorization, so if you're pressed for time for some reason, you should consider an easier course. So far, though, this is my favorite course of the semester. If you like to learn new or interesting things, take it.

His enthusiam for his subject makes the class more enjoyable.  He is big on attendence and you really score brownie points by attending any special lectures he mentions.  It was a great class for AH majors and non AH majors alike.  Take the 4th credit because it is only a few extra pages on each paper and you can use a paper in place of the final.
